elements.content: A series of novel organic–inorganic complexes based on trivalent lanthanide and HOOC–C6H4–CH2PO(OH)(OC2H5) (H2L′) formulated as Ln(HL)(H2L)(H2O) (H3 L = HOOC–C6H4–CH2PO(OH)2, Ln = La, 1; Ce, 2; Pr, 3; Nd, 4; Sm, 5; Eu, 6; Gd, 7; and Tb, 8) have been obtained as single phases by regulating the pH values under hydrothermal conditions. They are isomorphous and feature a network in which the LnO7 polyhedra are interconnected by bridging CPO3 tetrahedra into inorganic layers. These layers are further cross-linked by hydrogen bonds of the carboxyl acid groups of ligands into a S-shape pillared framework architecture. Luminescent measurements indicate that complexes 1–5 and 7 exhibit ligand-centered blue light emission bands. Complexes 6 and 8 display Ln-centered strong red and green luminescence, respectively. To elucidate the energy transfer process between ligands and metal ions, the energy levels of the relevant electronic states have been estimated. Simultaneously Eu3+ and Tb3+ were observed to accept energy with their several different 5D j , resonance levels depending on the lowest triplet state energy level of the ligand. Magnetic properties of 7 and 8 have also been studied.

elements.content:
The manifold 5D j levels of Eu3+ and Tb3+ can accept energy from the triplet state of the ligand under ultraviolet radiation and then emit red and green luminescence with the electron transition.

Introduction

As an attractive class of materials, organic–inorganic complexes based on metal phosphonates have received considerable attention over the last two decades due to their potential applications in ion exchange, sensor devices, catalysis, magnetic, and luminescent materials. So far, a great number of metal phosphonates with intriguing structures have been successfully constructed by careful selection of phosphonic acids and metal ions. Lanthanide complexes exhibit intense luminescence because of the long-lived (milliseconds timescale) excited states of Ln3+ ions. Luminescence has been instrumental, and these lanthanide elements have played important roles in lighting and light conversion technologies such as lasers, cathode-ray, and plasma displays and light-emitting diodes. This led to some most interesting developments in the coordination chemistry of lanthanide ions. Remarkably, the mostly studied complexes of Eu3+ and Tb3+ could exhibit intensely visible linelike emission. The first reported lanthanide phosphonate was prepared in 1985 by McCabe et al. They prepared the erbium phosphonate with a composition of Er(NO3)3[(i-C3H7O)2P(O)CH[C(O)N(C2H5)2] [CH2C(O)N(C2H5)2]]2·H2O. However, reports on lanthanide phosphonates are rather limited and some of their structures were determined by X-ray powder diffraction. It is well-known that lanthanide phosphonates normally have low solubility in water and organic solvents, leading to the difficulty in obtaining suitable single crystals for X-ray structural determination. To improve the solubility and crystallinity of lanthanide phosphonates, one effective approach is the introduction of various functional groups, such as hydroxy, pyridyl, crown ethers, sulfonates, and carboxylates to the phosphonate ligands. The adopting of a second ligand such as 4,4′-bipy or an oxalate anion has also been proven to be another useful way for the isolation of single crystals of lanthanide phosphonates. Phosphonic acids functionalized with carboxylate groups are versatile ligands, since both carboxylate and phosphonate groups are capable of binding the Ln3+ ion and adopting a variety of coordination modes under different experimental conditions. The first Ln3+ phosphonate containing a carboxylate group was reported by Legendziewicz et al. By using N-phosphomethyl-glycine (H2O3PCH2NHCH2COOH), a layered Eu3+ complex, {Eu2(HO3PCH2NH2CH2COO)2(H2O)7(ClO4)}[(ClO4)3]·H2O, was obtained. Its emission spectrum exhibits two, five, six, and eight lines, corresponding to the 5D0 → 7F j transitions (where j = 0, 1, 2, 4), which confirms the presence of two types of symmetries for the Eu3+ ions. Serre et al. reported a new three-dimensional (3D) lanthanide complex of a carboxylate phosphonic acid derived from piperidine-4-carboxylic acid (HO2C–C5H10N–CH2–PO3H2). Optical studies of its yttrium analogue doped at 3.4% with europium [MIL-84 (Y, Eu)] revealed a significant red-orange emission under ultraviolet (UV) radiation. By using 4-HOOC–C6H4–CH2NHCH2PO3H2 (H3pab), Mao et al. afforded nine new lanthanide (III) carboxylate–phosphonates with two types of 3D network structures, namely, LnCl(Hpab)(H2O)2 (Ln = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Er) and [Ln2(Hpab)(H2pab)(pab)(H2O)2]·4H2O (Ln = Nd, Sm, Eu). Luminescent measurements indicate that the complexes of Eu, Tb, and Dy show strong emission bands in the red, green, and yellow light region, respectively. Magnetic measurements indicate the ferromagnetic interaction between magnetic centers in the Nd, Gd, and Dy complexes. In summary, the introduction of the carboxylic group to the phosphonate ligands can not only improve the solubility and crystallinity of their Ln3+ complexes but also lead to the production of novel structures with different properties. However, reports on the structures and luminescence and magnetic properties of lanthanide arylphosphonates, especially the studies on the luminescence mechanism, are still scarce. We choose monocarboxyarylphosphonate ethyl ester (H2L′) with rigid phenyl group and flexible methylene group to investigate structures, luminescence properties, and mechanisms of its complexes with Ln3+. The carboxyarylphosphonate (H3L) and its transition metal complexes (M = Mn, Cu, Cd) were prepared in the previous literature. We synthesized H2L′ with commercial 4-chloromethyl-benzonitrile by the Arbuzov reaction, according to new procedures (Scheme ).

elements.content:
(i) P(OEt)3, reflux, 6 h. (ii) 20 wt % NaOH/H2O, reflux, 8 h. (iii) 6 M HCl.

Hydrothermal reactions of H2L′ with lanthanide (III) nitrates through regulating the pH afforded eight novel lanthanide carboxylate-phosphonate complexes, namely, Ln(HL)(H2L)(H2O) (Ln = La, 1; Ce, 2; Pr, 3; Nd, 4; Sm, 5; Eu, 6; Gd, 7; Tb, 8). Herein, we report their syntheses, crystal structures, thermal behaviors, luminescent, magnetic properties, and the possible energy transfer mechanism between ligands and Ln3+ ions based on the determination of the lowest triplet energy level of the ligand.

a (i) P(OEt)3, reflux, 6 h. (ii) 20 wt % NaOH/H2O, reflux, 8 h. (iii) 6 M HCl.  

Hydrothermal reactions of H2L' with lanthanide (III) nitrates through regulating the pH afforded eight novel lanthanide carboxylate-phosphonate complexes, namely, Ln(HL)(H2L)(H2O) (Ln = La, 1; Ce, 2; Pr, 3; Nd, 4; Sm, 5; Eu, 6; Gd, 7; Tb, 8). Herein, we report their syntheses, crystal structures, thermal behaviors, luminescent, magnetic properties, and the possible energy transfer mechanism between ligands and Ln3+ ions based on the determination of the lowest triplet energy level of the ligand.

elements.content: All commercially available chemicals were of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. Hydrated lanthanide (III) nitrates were prepared in the usual way by evaporating the solution of the corresponding oxide (99.9%) in HNO3. All hydrothermal syntheses were carried out in 23 mL of poly(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. The initial and final pH of the reaction were measured using a pH instrument. Elemental analyses of C and H were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 Fourier transform-infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer equipped with a DTGS detector (32 scans) by using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected with Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) radiation on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer. Electronic absorption spectra in the UV–vis region were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 35 UV–visible spectrophotometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer STA 6000 with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in a temperature range from 30 to 800 °C under atmosphere. The proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance III 400 MHz spectrometer in DMSO solution. Excitation and emission spectra were measured with an Edinburgh FLS 920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Luminescence lifetimes were recorded on a single photon counting spectrometer from Edinburgh Instrument (FLS 920) with microsecond pulse lamp as the excitation. The data were analyzed by software supplied by Edinburgh Instruments. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer. The raw data were corrected for the susceptibility of the container and the diamagnetic contributions of the sample using Pascal constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All commercially available chemicals were of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. Hydrated lanthanide (III) nitrates were prepared in the usual way by evaporating the solution of the corresponding oxide (99.9%) in HNO3. All hydrothermal syntheses were carried out in 23 mL of poly(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. The initial and final pH of the reaction were measured using a pH instrument. Elemental analyses of C and H were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 Fourier transform-infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer equipped with a DTGS detector (32 scans) by using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected with Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) radiation on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer. Electronic absorption spectra in the UV-vis region were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 35 UV-visible spectrophotometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer STA 6000 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in a temperature range from 30 to 800 °C under atmosphere. The proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance III 400 MHz spectrometer in DMSO solution. Excitation and emission spectra were measured with an Edinburgh FLS 920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Luminescence lifetimes were recorded on a single photon counting spectrometer from Edinburgh Instrument (FLS 920) with microsecond pulse lamp as the excitation. The data were analyzed by software supplied by Edinburgh Instruments. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer. The raw data were corrected for the susceptibility of the container and the diamagnetic contributions of the sample using Pascal constants.

elements.content: Triethyl phosphite (33.2 g, 0.20 mol) was added dropwise into 4-chloromethyl-benzonitrile (15.2 g, 0.10 mol) under rigorous stirring. After reacting for 6 h at about 150 °C, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and unreacted triethyl phosphite was removed by distillation in vacuo (749 mmHg). An aqueous solution of 20% sodium hydroxide (60 mL, 0.30 mol) was added in and refluxed for 8 h. The residual solution was then acidified with 6 M hydrochloric acid solution until the pH value reached 1.0. The resulting precipitate was filtered off and washed by 50 mL of cold deionized water, followed by vacuum drying to give the ligand in 75.8% yield (18.5 g). H2L′ was characterized by elemental analyses, UV, 1H NMR, and FT-IR (Figure S1–3 of the ). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C10H13O5P: C, 49.19; H, 5.37. Found: C, 49.11; H, 5.29. UV (MeOH): 208, 244 nm. 1H NMR (DMSO): δ 7.85 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 7.39–7.37 (m, 2H), 3.93–3.86 (m, 2H), 3.14 (d, J = 21.6 Hz, 2H), 1.16 ppm (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H). FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3416(m), 2840(s, w), 1693(vs), 1611(m), 1428(s), 1295(s), 1178(s), 1063(vs), 992(vs), 943(vs), 865(m), 539(s).

Synthesis of Monocarboxyarylphosphonate Ethyl Ester (H2L')

Triethyl phosphite (33.2 g, 0.20 mol) was added dropwise into 4-chloromethyl-benzonitrile (15.2 g, 0.10 mol) under rigorous stirring. After reacting for 6 h at about 150 °C, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and unreacted triethyl phosphite was removed by distillation in vacuo (749 mmHg). An aqueous solution of 20% sodium hydroxide (60 mL, 0.30 mol) was added in and refluxed for 8 h. The residual solution was then acidified with 6 M hydrochloric acid solution until the pH value reached 1.0. The resulting precipitate was filtered off and washed by 50 mL of cold deionized water, followed by vacuum drying to give the ligand in 75.8% yield (18.5 g). H2L' was characterized by elemental analyses, UV, 1H NMR, and FT-IR (Figure S1-3 of the ). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C10H13O5P: C, 49.19; H, 5.37. Found: C, 49.11; H, 5.29. UV (MeOH): 208, 244 nm. 1H NMR (DMSO): δ 7.85 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 7.39-7.37 (m, 2H), 3.93-3.86 (m, 2H), 3.14 (d, J = 21.6 Hz, 2H), 1.16 ppm (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H). FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3416(m), 2840(s, w), 1693(vs), 1611(m), 1428(s), 1295(s), 1178(s), 1063(vs), 992(vs), 943(vs), 865(m), 539(s).

elements.content: A mixture of La(NO3)3·6H2O (0.043 g, 0.10 mmol) and H2L′ (0.049 g, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of distilled water at room temperature. After the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 3.05 with 1.0 M HNO3, the suspension was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 140 °C and kept for 3 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature, the final pH value of the solution decreased to 0.98. Colorless rodlike crystals were filtered and washed with distilled water (56.8% yield based on La). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C16H17O11P2La: C, 32.79; H, 2.92. Found: C, 32.58; H, 2.98. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3523(w), 2915(m), 1686(s), 1611(m), 1577(w), 1427(m), 1291(m), 1187(m), 1071(vs), 1011(s), 977(s), 909(m), 864(w), 848(w), 786(w), 697(m), 638(w), 560(m), 477(w).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for complexes 1–8 were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID imaging plate diffractometer with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 291 K. Empirical absorption corrections based on equivalent reflections were applied. The structures of 1–8 were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using the SHELXS-97 crystallographic software package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for 1–8 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1 (see the ). Crystallography data have been deposited to the Cambridge Crystallography Data Centre with deposition numbers CCDC: 911380–911387 for 1–8, respectively.

X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for complexes 1-8 were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID imaging plate diffractometer with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 291 K. Empirical absorption corrections based on equivalent reflections were applied. The structures of 1-8 were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F  2  using the SHELXS-97 crystallographic software package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for 1-8 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1 (see the ). Crystallography data have been deposited to the Cambridge Crystallography Data Centre with deposition numbers CCDC: 911380-911387 for 1-8, respectively.

elements.content: All complexes 1–8 were prepared under hydrothermal conditions (140 °C, 3 days) by reactions of hydrated lanthanide (III) nitrate and H2L′ at a molar ratio of 1:2. The pH values of the reaction mixtures were found to greatly affect the crystals growth of 1–8. When NaOH was used as a base to adjust the pH, the product was obtained in the form of a fine powder. In addition, lower pH was helpful for the formation of suitable single-crystals for X-ray diffraction. For complex 1, the reaction pH value in the range of 2.56–3.33 yields a pure crystal phase of the resultant; however, a pH of less than 2.56 results in a solution, and a pH above 3.33 leads to a powder. For complex 2, a pure crystal phase can be obtained in the pH range of 2.49–2.58. Similarly, products with good crystal quality can be gained with the pH range of 2.47–2.56 for 3, 2.43–2.53 for 4, 2.41–2.51 for 5, 2.33–2.44 for 6, 2.31–2.49 for 7, and 2.26–2.35 for 8, respectively (Figure ). In accordance with the order of the lanthanum contraction, a successive lower pH value is favorable for the growth of crystal from La to Tb. For heavier Ln ions (behind Tb), we did not get suitable single crystals for X-ray diffraction. The results of this study may provide powerful evidence of pH value playing an important role in the growth of single crystals.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis

All complexes 1-8 were prepared under hydrothermal conditions (140 °C, 3 days) by reactions of hydrated lanthanide (III) nitrate and H2L' at a molar ratio of 1:2. The pH values of the reaction mixtures were found to greatly affect the crystals growth of 1-8. When NaOH was used as a base to adjust the pH, the product was obtained in the form of a fine powder. In addition, lower pH was helpful for the formation of suitable single-crystals for X-ray diffraction. For complex 1, the reaction pH value in the range of 2.56-3.33 yields a pure crystal phase of the resultant; however, a pH of less than 2.56 results in a solution, and a pH above 3.33 leads to a powder. For complex 2, a pure crystal phase can be obtained in the pH range of 2.49-2.58. Similarly, products with good crystal quality can be gained with the pH range of 2.47-2.56 for 3, 2.43-2.53 for 4, 2.41-2.51 for 5, 2.33-2.44 for 6, 2.31-2.49 for 7, and 2.26-2.35 for 8, respectively (Figure ). In accordance with the order of the lanthanum contraction, a successive lower pH value is favorable for the growth of crystal from La to Tb. For heavier Ln ions (behind Tb), we did not get suitable single crystals for X-ray diffraction. The results of this study may provide powerful evidence of pH value playing an important role in the growth of single crystals.

elements.content: All complexes 1–8 are isomorphous and feature a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure. It is found that all eight complexes crystallize in a triclinic system, space group Pi̅. Hence, only the structure of 1 will be discussed in detail as a representative. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one La3+ ion, two ligands (HL2– and H2L–) which adopt two different types of coordination modes, and one coordinated water molecule (Figure a). The coordination modes of the ligand are depicted in Figure b: (i) The HL2– anion acts as a three-connected linker, coordinating to three equivalent La3+ ions by its three phosphonate oxygen atoms with bridging and chelating modes. (ii) The H2L– anion acts as a two-connected bridging linker via two phosphonate oxygen atoms. Each La3+ is seven-coordinated with six positions occupied by phosphonate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O6, O2I, O3II, and O8III) from five ligands and the remaining site occupied by O11 from one water molecule (Figure c). Coordination number of La3+ is usually eight in reported La3+ phosphonates and decreases in the lanthanide series. The observed coordination number 7, even for La3+, is responsible for ligand coordination in a different way such that the 2D network cannot accommodate NO3 –. Its coordination geometry could be described as a distorted pentagonal bipyramid, {LaO7} (Figure d). The bond lengths of La–O are between 2.359(3) and 2.606(4) Å, and the angles around La3+ range from 55.96(11)° to 168.41(13)° (Table S1 of the ). Two edge-to-edge La3+ polyhedra alternate in a chain to the [110] direction, and the distance between adjacent La3+ is 4.239(1) Å. These are in turn connected via phosphonate groups along the [110] direction forming the inorganic layer (Figure e). Overall, the structure can be described as the stacking of 2D layers, with a layer-to-layer separation of 18.30(1) Å. Ligands acted as S-shape pillars supporting inorganic layers along the c axis (Figure f). The interconnections of ligands take place through hydrogen bonds (Table S2 of the ), involving the carboxylic acid groups within the organic layer (Figure g).

Crystal Structure Description

All complexes 1-8 are isomorphous and feature a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure. It is found that all eight complexes crystallize in a triclinic system, space group Pi̅. Hence, only the structure of 1 will be discussed in detail as a representative. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one La3+ ion, two ligands (HL2- and H2L-) which adopt two different types of coordination modes, and one coordinated water molecule (Figure a). The coordination modes of the ligand are depicted in Figure b: (i) The HL2- anion acts as a three-connected linker, coordinating to three equivalent La3+ ions by its three phosphonate oxygen atoms with bridging and chelating modes. (ii) The H2L- anion acts as a two-connected bridging linker via two phosphonate oxygen atoms. Each La3+ is seven-coordinated with six positions occupied by phosphonate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O6, O2I, O3II, and O8III) from five ligands and the remaining site occupied by O11 from one water molecule (Figure c). Coordination number of La3+ is usually eight in reported La3+ phosphonates and decreases in the lanthanide series. The observed coordination number 7, even for La3+, is responsible for ligand coordination in a different way such that the 2D network cannot accommodate NO3 -. Its coordination geometry could be described as a distorted pentagonal bipyramid, {LaO7} (Figure d). The bond lengths of La-O are between 2.359(3) and 2.606(4) Å, and the angles around La3+ range from 55.96(11)° to 168.41(13)° (Table S1 of the ). Two edge-to-edge La3+ polyhedra alternate in a chain to the [110] direction, and the distance between adjacent La3+ is 4.239(1) Å. These are in turn connected via phosphonate groups along the [110] direction forming the inorganic layer (Figure e). Overall, the structure can be described as the stacking of 2D layers, with a layer-to-layer separation of 18.30(1) Å. Ligands acted as S-shape pillars supporting inorganic layers along the c axis (Figure f). The interconnections of ligands take place through hydrogen bonds (Table S2 of the ), involving the carboxylic acid groups within the organic layer (Figure g).

The crystal samples of complexes 1–8 were gently ground in an agate mortar in order to minimize the preferred orientation. High-resolution X-ray diffraction measurement collected at room temperature over the angular 2θ range from 4.5–50° with a step of 0.013° and a counting time of 7 s. The PXRD patterns of 1–8 were compared with the calculated 1 (Figure ), indicating that the products have been successfully obtained as pure crystalline phases. The PXRD patterns of other Ln3+ (selected Er3+ and Lu3+) complexes demonstrate identical phases with 1–8 (Figure S4 of the ).

elements.content: FT-IR spectra of ligand and complexes 1–8 are depicted in Figure S3 of the . The sharp band at 3523 cm–1 could be ascribed to the stretching vibration of the coordinated water molecules. The wide bands from 3400 to 2000 cm–1, arising from the O–H stretching vibrations of protonated phosphonate oxygen and carboxylic acid, suggest that extensive hydrogen bonds are present in the complexes because of the spectrum diffusion. The strong band around 1686 cm–1 can be attributed to the CO vibration of the COOH group, indicating that the COOH is involved in the formation of hydrogen bonds. The very strong band at 1071 cm–1 may be due to the blue shift of the PO vibration resulted from the Ln3+ coordination effect. The bands at 1011, 977 (strong), and 909 (medium) cm–1 are characteristic stretching vibrations of the tetrahedral CPO3 group. Bands at 848 and 738 cm–1 are attributed to the C–H out-of-plane vibrations for the para-disubstituted phenylene ring. The band at 786 cm–1 is characteristic of the P–C stretching vibration. Bands between 638 cm–1 and 477 cm–1 mainly correspond to the bending modes of the CPO3 group. However, the band at 560 cm–1 may be assigned to the Ln–O stretching vibration.

FT-IR Spectra

The wide bands from 3400 to 2000 cm-1, arising from the O-H stretching vibrations of protonated phosphonate oxygen and carboxylic acid, suggest that extensive hydrogen bonds are present in the complexes because of the spectrum diffusion. The strong band around 1686 cm-1 can be attributed to the CO vibration of the COOH group, indicating that the COOH is involved in the formation of hydrogen bonds. The very strong band at 1071 cm-1 may be due to the blue shift of the PO vibration resulted from the Ln3+ coordination effect. The bands at 1011, 977 (strong), and 909 (medium) cm-1 are characteristic stretching vibrations of the tetrahedral CPO3 group. Bands at 848 and 738 cm-1 are attributed to the C-H out-of-plane vibrations for the para-disubstituted phenylene ring. The band at 786 cm-1 is characteristic of the P-C stretching vibration. Bands between 638 cm-1 and 477 cm-1 mainly correspond to the bending modes of the CPO3 group. However, the band at 560 cm-1 may be assigned to the Ln-O stretching vibration.

elements.content: The thermal stabilities in the air of complexes 1–8 were investigated. The TG curves of 1–8 are similar and exhibit three main steps of weight loss (Figure ). The curves show an unusual thermal stability. Complex 1 was used as an example. (i) Dehydration occurs only after ca. 260 °C. Up to 290 °C, almost all the coordinated water molecules are removed with 3.1% weight loss (calculated value 3.07). (ii) From 430 to 560 °C, further rapid weight loss corresponds to partial combustion of the organic ligand. (iii) After 560 °C, the complex continues to decompose slowly. The decomposing process would not end until 800 °C, with La2(PO4)3 as the possible final product. The TG curves show that the complexes are highly thermally stable.

elements.content: The solid-state luminescent spectra of ligand and complexes 1–8 are investigated at room temperature. The free ligands exhibit broad fluorescent emission bands at 436 and 467 nm, respectively, under excitation at 380 nm (Figure a). Complexes 1–5 have broad ligand-centered (LC) fluorescence spectra (Figure S5 of the and Figure b). However, complexes 4 and 5 do not show characteristic emission bands of the Nd3+ and Sm3+, which indicate that the energy absorption of the ligand can be transferred to the excited state of the Ln3+ ion, followed by vibration quenching; complex 6 exhibits hybrid emission of the Eu3+ ion and ligand consisting of five characteristic emission bands for the Eu3+ ion in the visible region and 444 and 467 nm bands for the ligand under excitation at 375 nm (Figure c). These emission bands are 579 nm (very weak, 5D0 → 7F0), 587, 593, and 595 nm (weak, 5D0 → 7F1), 609, 613, 621 nm (very strong, 5D0→ 7F2), 652 nm (very weak, 5D0 → 7F3), and 695, 699, 704 nm (weak, 5D0 → 7F4). The splitting of 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, and 5D0 → 7F4 transition bands is due to the “crystal field effect” of the Eu (III) ion in a C s symmetry, which led to the complete degeneracy of the 7F1 and the partial degeneracy of the 7F j (j = 2 and 4) states. The 5D0 → 7F2 transition is very intense, which is allowed by the electric dipole and hypersensitive to the environment in the vicinity of Eu3+ ion, showing strong red emisions. The unique sharp band for the 5D0 → 7F0 transition confirms the existence of one coordination type of Eu3+ with C s symmetry in the structure. The Eu3+ (5D0) lifetime (λex,em = 375 and 609 nm, respectively) is measured to be 0.44 ms (Figure S6a of the ). The emission spectrum of complex 7 only exhibits a broad blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 411 nm (λex = 375 nm) (Figure d), which corresponds to a ligand-centered (LC) fluorescence. Complex 8 shows four characteristic emission bands for the Tb3+ ion in the visible region under an excitation at 296 nm (Figure e). These emission bands are 490 nm (weak, 5D4 → 7F6), 548 nm (very strong, 5D4 → 7F5), 582 and 594 nm (weak, 5D4 → 7F4), and 609 and 620 nm (weak, 5D4 → 7F3), respectively. The strongest one is the green luminescence of the 5D4 → 7F5 transition. The Tb3+ (5D4) lifetime (λex,em = 296 and 548 nm) is 0.93 ms (Figure S6b of the ). Viewing 6 and 8 under a dark-field luminescence microscope, brilliant red and green luminescences were revealed when they were illuminated with UV light in Figure .

The Eu3+ (5D0) lifetime (λex,em = 375 and 609 nm, respectively) is measured to be 0.44 ms (Figure S6a of the ). The emission spectrum of complex 7 only exhibits a broad blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 411 nm (λex = 375 nm) (Figure d), which corresponds to a ligand-centered (LC) fluorescence. Complex 8 shows four characteristic emission bands for the Tb3+ ion in the visible region under an excitation at 296 nm (Figure e). These emission bands are 490 nm (weak, 5D4 → 7F6), 548 nm (very strong, 5D4 → 7F5), 582 and 594 nm (weak, 5D4 → 7F4), and 609 and 620 nm (weak, 5D4 → 7F3), respectively. The strongest one is the green luminescence of the 5D4 → 7F5 transition. The Tb3+ (5D4) lifetime (λex,em = 296 and 548 nm) is 0.93 ms (Figure S6b of the ). Viewing 6 and 8 under a dark-field luminescence microscope, brilliant red and green luminescences were revealed when they were illuminated with UV light in Figure .

elements.content: To demonstrate the energy transfer process, the phosphorescence spectrum of the Gd complex was measured for the triplet state energy level data of the ligand at 77 K in a solution of methanol (1 × 10–5 mol L–1). From the phosphorescence spectra (Figure f), the triplet state energy level (3 ππ*) of 7 is 26670 cm–1 (375 nm), which corresponds to its first peak emission wavelength. Because the lowest excited state 6P7/2 of Gd3+ is too high to accept energy from the ligand, the data obtained from the phosphorescence spectra actually reveal the 3 ππ* of the ligand. On the basis of the above experimental results, the energy level diagram and the possible energy transfer pathways are shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Energy Transfer

To demonstrate the energy transfer process, the phosphorescence spectrum of the Gd complex was measured for the triplet state energy level data of the ligand at 77 K in a solution of methanol (1 × 10-5 mol L-1). From the phosphorescence spectra (Figure f), the triplet state energy level (3 ππ*) of 7 is 26670 cm-1 (375 nm), which corresponds to its first peak emission wavelength. Because the lowest excited state 6P7/2 of Gd3+ is too high to accept energy from the ligand, the data obtained from the phosphorescence spectra actually reveal the 3 ππ* of the ligand. On the basis of the above experimental results, the energy level diagram and the possible energy transfer pathways are shown in Figure .

elements.content: In general, the sensitization pathway in luminescent Eu3+ complexes consists of excitation of the ligands into their excited singlet states, subsequent ISC of the ligands to their triplet states, and the ET from the triplet state to the manifold 5D j of the Eu3+ ions, followed by internal conversion to the emitting 5D0 state. Finally, the Eu3+ ion emission occurs with the transition to the ground state. Moreover, the electron transitions from the higher excited states, such as 5D3 (24800 cm–1), 5D2 (21200 cm–1), and 5D1 (19000 cm–1), to 5D0 (17500 cm–1) become feasible by internal conversion, and most of the photophysical processes take place in this orbital. Thus, matching the 3 ππ* of the ligands to 5D j of Eu3+ is one of the key factors that affect the luminescent properties of the Eu3+ complexes. The energy transfer process for Tb3+ can be summarized in three steps. Absorbed energy is transferred from the 1 ππ* to the 3 ππ* of ligands, and then from the 3 ππ* to the emitting 5D0 level of the Tb3+ ion directly. Finally, energy is transferred from the emitting level to 7F j of Tb3+.

elements.content: The temperature dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 7 (500 Oe) and 8 (1000 Oe) were measured in the range of 300–1.8 K, and they display similar magnetic properties. For 7, the χM T versus T plots show that χM T (8.60 cm3 K mol–1, 300 K) decreases slowly upon cooling and reaches a minimum of 8.17 cm3 K mol–1 at 30.0 K, indicating an antiferromagnetic interaction between magnetic centers. Below 30 K, it increases rapidly to a maximum (10.01 cm3 K mol–1) at 1.8 K, indicating the presence of possible ferromagnetic interactions between the 2D layers. The room temperature effective magnetic moments (μeff) of 8.29 μB is more than the theoretical value of 7.94 μB for an isolated Gd3+ ion (8S7/2, S = 7/2, L = 0, g = 2) calculated according to the Van Vleck formula. The inverse of the χM data obeys the Curie–Weiss law above 30 K (Figure a), with a Curie constant (C M) of 8.64 cm3 K mol–1 and a Weiss constant (θ) of −2.63 K. Fitting of the data under 30 K, according to the Curie–Weiss law, gave a C M of 8.10 cm3 K mol–1 and a small positive θ of 0.38 K. The field dependence of the magnetization of 7 is investigated at 1.8 K (Figure b). The magnetization increases sharply to 0.3 Nβ with the increasing magnetic field and saturates at 38 kOe and then slowly declines 0.27 Nβ at 70 kOe.

Magnetic Property Measurements

The temperature dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 7 (500 Oe) and 8 (1000 Oe) were measured in the range of 300-1.8 K, and they display similar magnetic properties. For 7, the χM T versus T plots show that χM T (8.60 cm3 K mol-1, 300 K) decreases slowly upon cooling and reaches a minimum of 8.17 cm3 K mol-1 at 30.0 K, indicating an antiferromagnetic interaction between magnetic centers. Below 30 K, it increases rapidly to a maximum (10.01 cm3 K mol-1) at 1.8 K, indicating the presence of possible ferromagnetic interactions between the 2D layers. The room temperature effective magnetic moments (μeff) of 8.29 μB is more than the theoretical value of 7.94 μB for an isolated Gd3+ ion (8S7/2, S = 7/2, L = 0, g = 2) calculated according to the Van Vleck formula. The inverse of the χM data obeys the Curie-Weiss law above 30 K (Figure a), with a Curie constant (C M) of 8.64 cm3 K mol-1 and a Weiss constant (θ) of -2.63 K. Fitting of the data under 30 K, according to the Curie-Weiss law, gave a C M of 8.10 cm3 K mol-1 and a small positive θ of 0.38 K. The field dependence of the magnetization of 7 is investigated at 1.8 K (Figure b). The magnetization increases sharply to 0.3 Nβ with the increasing magnetic field and saturates at 38 kOe and then slowly declines 0.27 Nβ at 70 kOe.

elements.content: For 8, during the process of the temperature descending, the χM T decreases gradually from 8.30 cm3 K mol–1 (300 K) to 6.75 cm3 K mol–1 (25 K), and then quickly increases to a maximum of 10.56 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K (Figure c). At 300 K, the effective magnetic moment (μeff = 8.15 μB) is much smaller than the expected value of 9.72 μB for an isolated Tb3+ ion (7F6, S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2). The plot of 1/χM versus T obeys the Curie–Weiss law. Fitting of the data above 25 K gets a C M of 8.64 cm3 K mol–1 and a θ of −13.0 K. Fitting of the data under 25 K gives a C M of 6.52 cm3 K mol–1 and a θ of 0.93 K. The field-dependent isothermal magnetization measured at 1.8 K reveals that the magnetization displays an abrupt increase to 2.40 Nβ below 6 kOe and then slowly reaches 2.83 Nβ at 70 kOe. Little hysteresis loop was observed, suggesting that the magnetic phase critical temperature (T C) is probably higher than 1.8 K (Figure d). These correspond to a typical ferrimagnetic behavior in a crystal system with dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between the Ln3+ ions.

elements.content: Eight new lanthanide phosphonates with a 2D framework structure have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions through adjusting pH. All complexes have been obtained as single phase and exhibit very high thermal stability, and their photoluminescence properties are also discussed. Complexes 1–5 and 7 exhibit ligand-centered blue light emission. Complexes 6 and 8 display Ln-centered red and green luminescence, respectively. Energy transfer studies demonstrate the possible luminescence mechanism. Magnetic properties of complexes 7 and 8 indicate that there are antiferromagnetic interactions above T C and ferromagnetic interactions under T C between Ln3+ ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Eight new lanthanide phosphonates with a 2D framework structure have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions through adjusting pH. All complexes have been obtained as single phase and exhibit very high thermal stability, and their photoluminescence properties are also discussed. Complexes 1-5 and 7 exhibit ligand-centered blue light emission. Complexes 6 and 8 display Ln-centered red and green luminescence, respectively. Energy transfer studies demonstrate the possible luminescence mechanism. Magnetic properties of complexes 7 and 8 indicate that there are antiferromagnetic interactions above T C and ferromagnetic interactions under T C between Ln3+ ions.

elements.content: Crystallographic data in CIF for complexes 1–8; 1H NMR spectrum for H2L′, UV, and FT-IR spectra for H2L′ and complexes 1–8; PXRD patterns for complexes Er and Lu; solid-state excitation and emission spectra for complexes 1–4; solid-state luminescence lifetime curves for complexes 6 and 8. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

Triethyl phosphite (33.2 g, 0.20 mol) was added dropwise into 4-chloromethyl-benzonitrile (15.2 g, 0.10 mol) under rigorous stirring. After reacting for 6 h at about 150 °C, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and unreacted triethyl phosphite was removed by distillation in vacuo (749 mmHg). An aqueous solution of 20% sodium hydroxide (60 mL, 0.30 mol) was added in and refluxed for 8 h. The residual solution was then acidified with 6 M hydrochloric acid solution until the pH value reached 1.0. The resulting precipitate was filtered off and washed by 50 mL of cold deionized water, followed by vacuum drying to give the ligand in 75.8% yield (18.5 g). H2L′ was characterized by elemental analyses, UV, 1H NMR, and FT-IR (Figure S1–3 of the ). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C10H13O5P: C, 49.19; H, 5.37. Found: C, 49.11; H, 5.29. UV (MeOH): 208, 244 nm. 1H NMR (DMSO): δ 7.85 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 7.39–7.37 (m, 2H), 3.93–3.86 (m, 2H), 3.14 (d, J = 21.6 Hz, 2H), 1.16 ppm (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H). FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3416(m), 2840(s, w), 1693(vs), 1611(m), 1428(s), 1295(s), 1178(s), 1063(vs), 992(vs), 943(vs), 865(m), 539(s).

Synthesis of La(HL)(H<sub>2</sub>L)(H<sub>2</sub>O) (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of La(NO3)3·6H2O (0.043 g, 0.10 mmol) and H2L′ (0.049 g, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of distilled water at room temperature. After the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 3.05 with 1.0 M HNO3, the suspension was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 140 °C and kept for 3 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature, the final pH value of the solution decreased to 0.98. Colorless rodlike crystals were filtered and washed with distilled water (56.8% yield based on La). Found: C, 31.79; H, 2.91. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3505(w), 2918(m), 1685(s), 1611(m), 1578(w), 1427(m), 1292(m), 1192(m), 1082(vs), 1013(s), 986(s), 900(m), 865(w), 786(w), 698(m), 633(w), 564(m), 477(w).

Synthesis of Gd(HL)(H2L)(H2O) (7)

The procedure was the same as that for 1, except that La(NO3)3⋅6H2O was replaced by Gd(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.045 g, 0.10 mmol), and the pH was adjusted to 2.37. Colorless rodlike crystals were filtered and washed with distilled water (final pH: 0.86, 53.3% yield based on Gd). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C16H17O11P2Gd: C, 31.79; H, 2.83. Found: C, 31.65; H, 2.85. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3523(w), 2915(m), 1686(s), 1611(m), 1577(w), 1427(m), 1291(m), 1187(m), 1072(vs), 1011(s), 977(s), 909(m), 864(w), 848(w), 786(w), 697(m), 642(w), 561(m), 478(w).

Synthesis of Tb(HL)(H2L)(H2O) (8)

The procedure was the same as that for 1, except that La(NO3)3⋅6H2O was replaced by Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.045 g, 0.10 mmol), and the pH was adjusted to 2.30. Colorless rodlike crystals were filtered and washed with distilled water (final pH: 0.85, 41.6% yield based on Tb). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C16H17O11P2Tb: C, 31.70; H, 2.83. Found: C, 31.46; H, 2.87. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3503(w), 3013(m), 1685(s), 1612(m), 1578(w), 1428(m), 1292(m), 1194(m), 1082(vs), 1013(s), 985(s), 898(m), 865(w), 786(w), 698(m), 633(w), 564(m), 476(w).

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stabilities in the air of complexes 1–8 were investigated. The TG curves of 1–8 are similar and exhibit three main steps of weight loss (Figure ). The curves show an unusual thermal stability. Complex 1 was used as an example. (i) Dehydration occurs only after ca. 260 °C. Up to 290 °C, almost all the coordinated water molecules are removed with 3.1% weight loss (calculated value 3.07). (ii) From 430 to 560 °C, further rapid weight loss corresponds to partial combustion of the organic ligand. (iii) After 560 °C, the complex continues to decompose slowly. The decomposing process would not end until 800 °C, with La2(PO4)3 as the possible final product. The TG curves show that the complexes are highly thermally stable.

Luminescent Properties

The solid-state luminescent spectra of ligand and complexes 1–8 are investigated at room temperature. The free ligands exhibit broad fluorescent emission bands at 436 and 467 nm, respectively, under excitation at 380 nm (Figure a). Complexes 1–5 have broad ligand-centered (LC) fluorescence spectra (Figure S5 of the and Figure b). However, complexes 4 and 5 do not show characteristic emission bands of the Nd3+ and Sm3+, which indicate that the energy absorption of the ligand can be transferred to the excited state of the Ln3+ ion, followed by vibration quenching; complex 6 exhibits hybrid emission of the Eu3+ ion and ligand consisting of five characteristic emission bands for the Eu3+ ion in the visible region and 444 and 467 nm bands for the ligand under excitation at 375 nm (Figure c). These emission bands are 579 nm (very weak, 5D0 → 7F0), 587, 593, and 595 nm (weak, 5D0 → 7F1), 609, 613, 621 nm (very strong, 5D0→ 7F2), 652 nm (very weak, 5D0 → 7F3), and 695, 699, 704 nm (weak, 5D0 → 7F4). The splitting of 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, and 5D0 → 7F4 transition bands is due to the “crystal field effect” of the Eu (III) ion in a C s symmetry, which led to the complete degeneracy of the 7F1 and the partial degeneracy of the 7F j (j = 2 and 4) states. The 5D0 → 7F2 transition is very intense, which is allowed by the electric dipole and hypersensitive to the environment in the vicinity of Eu3+ ion, showing strong red emisions. The unique sharp band for the 5D0 → 7F0 transition confirms the existence of one coordination type of Eu3+ with C s symmetry in the structure. The Eu3+ (5D0) lifetime (λex,em = 375 and 609 nm, respectively) is measured to be 0.44 ms (Figure S6a of the ). The emission spectrum of complex 7 only exhibits a broad blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 411 nm (λex = 375 nm) (Figure d), which corresponds to a ligand-centered (LC) fluorescence. Complex 8 shows four characteristic emission bands for the Tb3+ ion in the visible region under an excitation at 296 nm (Figure e). These emission bands are 490 nm (weak, 5D4 → 7F6), 548 nm (very strong, 5D4 → 7F5), 582 and 594 nm (weak, 5D4 → 7F4), and 609 and 620 nm (weak, 5D4 → 7F3), respectively. The strongest one is the green luminescence of the 5D4 → 7F5 transition. The Tb3+ (5D4) lifetime (λex,em = 296 and 548 nm) is 0.93 ms (Figure S6b of the ). Viewing 6 and 8 under a dark-field luminescence microscope, brilliant red and green luminescences were revealed when they were illuminated with UV light in Figure .

Magnetic Property Measurements

The temperature dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 7 (500 Oe) and 8 (1000 Oe) were measured in the range of 300–1.8 K, and they display similar magnetic properties. For 7, the χM T versus T plots show that χM T (8.60 cm3 K mol–1, 300 K) decreases slowly upon cooling and reaches a minimum of 8.17 cm3 K mol–1 at 30.0 K, indicating an antiferromagnetic interaction between magnetic centers. Below 30 K, it increases rapidly to a maximum (10.01 cm3 K mol–1) at 1.8 K, indicating the presence of possible ferromagnetic interactions between the 2D layers. The room temperature effective magnetic moments (μeff) of 8.29 μB is more than the theoretical value of 7.94 μB for an isolated Gd3+ ion (8S7/2, S = 7/2, L = 0, g = 2) calculated according to the Van Vleck formula. The inverse of the χM data obeys the Curie–Weiss law above 30 K (Figure a), with a Curie constant (C M) of 8.64 cm3 K mol–1 and a Weiss constant (θ) of −2.63 K. Fitting of the data under 30 K, according to the Curie–Weiss law, gave a C M of 8.10 cm3 K mol–1 and a small positive θ of 0.38 K. The field dependence of the magnetization of 7 is investigated at 1.8 K (Figure b). The magnetization increases sharply to 0.3 Nβ with the increasing magnetic field and saturates at 38 kOe and then slowly declines 0.27 Nβ at 70 kOe.

For 8, during the process of the temperature descending, the χM T decreases gradually from 8.30 cm3 K mol–1 (300 K) to 6.75 cm3 K mol–1 (25 K), and then quickly increases to a maximum of 10.56 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K (Figure c). At 300 K, the effective magnetic moment (μeff = 8.15 μB) is much smaller than the expected value of 9.72 μB for an isolated Tb3+ ion (7F6, S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2). The plot of 1/χM versus T obeys the Curie–Weiss law. Fitting of the data above 25 K gets a C M of 8.64 cm3 K mol–1 and a θ of −13.0 K. Fitting of the data under 25 K gives a C M of 6.52 cm3 K mol–1 and a θ of 0.93 K. The field-dependent isothermal magnetization measured at 1.8 K reveals that the magnetization displays an abrupt increase to 2.40 Nβ below 6 kOe and then slowly reaches 2.83 Nβ at 70 kOe. Little hysteresis loop was observed, suggesting that the magnetic phase critical temperature (T C) is probably higher than 1.8 K (Figure d). These correspond to a typical ferrimagnetic behavior in a crystal system with dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between the Ln3+ ions.

pH-Dependent Syntheses, Luminescent, and Magnetic
